conclusion: The v-t graph represents the velocity of two objects, A and B, as a function of time.
The curve for object A is above the curve for object B throughout the entire time interval from t = 0 to t = t1.
At any given time t, the difference in speed between objects A and B is the vertical distance between the two curves.
At t = 0, both objects start at the same speed (both velocities are zero), so the difference in speed is zero.
At some intermediate time t, the difference in speed is positive and non-zero.
At t = t1, the difference in speed again becomes zero because both velocities return to zero.
From t = 0 to some point before t1, the vertical distance (difference in speed) increases as the curve for A rises faster than the curve for B.
After reaching a maximum difference somewhere before t1, the difference starts to decrease as both curves approach zero at t1.
The difference in speed is not continuously increasing; it increases to a maximum value and then decreases back to zero.
No, the difference in speed between the two objects is not continuously increasing during the time interval from 0 to t1. It increases to a maximum and then decreases.
